name: 2017_10_humanities_student_major_2574_mba
title: 2017-10-humanities-student-major_2574_MBA.txt
content_scrubbed:
MBA will be a lot more forgiving for a 3. 4 in engineering and a high GMAT will give you a shot at HSW, provided your other credentials are up to par. 

Your GPA most likely puts you DOA at H/S law; from what I have heard from law school friends, they do not really care about the rigor of your major. Hence, median GPAs at those schools is actually like 3. 9, with a lot of humanities_major. Probably still fine at Northwestern or Columbia if your LSAT is high enough. Check https://www. reddit. com/r/lawschooladmissions/ but I think they'd concur.

You also need to think hard on whether you really want to do a JD/MBA. You need strong reasons to answer the "why MBA" question, and doubly so for a JD/MBA. You don't want to be seen as someone looking to collect degrees.

MBA is a very holistic process, law is not. My co-worker got into Harvard and Stanford law with a 3. 9 GPA and 176 LSAT and 760 GMAT, didn't even get an interview at Harvard, Wharton, and Booth since he only had 2 years of experience at matriculation and no good narrative for why MBA.

As far as ECs, get involved with your community. If you're interested in politics, it[.] a very active time to be involved e. g., fighting for immigration rights. Just as important is figuring out your why MBA reason.
